On Tasmania, the thylacine lived in a variety of environments, including dry and wet forests, open woodlands, and grasslands. It likely favored areas where it could move quietly through cover while still finding plenty of prey, such as forest edges, river valleys, and scrubby plains.
The extinction of the thylacine is closely linked to human activity. After European settlement in Tasmania, it was widely blamed for killing sheep and was heavily persecuted. Bounty schemes encouraged large-scale hunting, and many animals were shot or trapped. Habitat loss, competition with introduced dogs, and diseases may also have contributed. By the early 1900s the species was extremely rare, and despite legal protection introduced too late, the last captive thylacine died in Hobart Zoo in 1936.
The thylacine’s pouch opened backward, which protected the young when the mother moved through dense vegetation. It could open its jaws to an angle of nearly 80 degrees - much wider than most dogs. Despite many alleged sightings after 1936, there is no confirmed evidence that the species survives today, making it one of the most famous examples of recent human-driven extinction.

Thylacoleo, often called the “marsupial lion”, was a powerful carnivorous marsupial that lived in Australia during the late Pleistocene, roughly between about 2 million and 40,000 years ago. Despite its nickname, it was not a true lion but a member of an entirely different mammal group - marsupials, which carry their young in a pouch.
An adult Thylacoleo was about the size of a large leopard or small lion. It likely reached around 1.1-1.5 meters in body length (not counting the tail) and weighed roughly 80-130 kilograms, with some big individuals possibly heavier. It had a compact, muscular body, powerful shoulders and forelimbs, and a relatively short face with a deep, strong jaw.
Thylacoleo was a specialized carnivore. Unlike typical cats, it did not have long canine teeth; instead, it had huge, blade-like premolars that worked like shears, perfect for slicing through flesh and bone. Its front paws carried large, retractable claws, including an especially big thumb claw used to grip and hold struggling prey. It likely hunted large animals such as giant kangaroos, large wombats, and other Pleistocene megafauna, using ambush rather than long chases.
This predator lived in a range of Australian environments, including open woodlands, forests, and scrublands. Fossils found in cave deposits suggest it may have used caves as dens or shelter. During its time, Australia hosted a unique Ice Age fauna, with giant kangaroos, enormous wombats like Diprotodon, and huge flightless birds, providing a variety of potential prey.
Thylacoleo went extinct around 40,000 years ago, roughly the same period when many other large Australian animals disappeared. The causes are still debated. Likely factors include climate change that altered habitats and water availability, along with the arrival and spread of humans, who may have hunted Thylacoleo’s prey or changed the landscape with fire.
Thylacoleo had one of the strongest bite forces relative to body size of any known mammal predator. Its retractable claws are rare among marsupials and convergently similar to those of true cats. Some scientists think it may have been able to climb trees or rocky cliffs, launching ambushes from above on passing prey.

Haast’s eagle (Hieraaetus moorei) was a gigantic bird of prey that lived on New Zealand’s South Island during the late Pleistocene and early Holocene, surviving until only about 600 years ago. It is considered the largest eagle known to have ever lived.
Adult Haast’s eagles had a body length up to about 1.3-1.4 meters, stood around 90 centimeters tall, and had a wingspan of roughly 2.6-3 meters. Females were larger than males, with most estimates putting them around 10-15 kilograms and possibly up to about 18 kilograms, while males were slightly smaller. Despite their great weight, their wings were relatively short for an eagle, giving them a compact, powerful build suited to maneuvering through forests rather than soaring long distances.
Like all eagles, Haast’s eagle was a carnivore. It was a top predator that specialized in hunting large, flightless birds, especially moa, some of which weighed more than 10 times as much as the eagle itself. Using enormous talons comparable in size to a tiger’s claws, it likely attacked from above, striking with great force, driving its claws into the back or hips of a moa, and then tearing into soft tissues with its strong, hooked beak. After the kill, it probably fed in a way similar to modern vultures, plunging its head deep into the body cavity to consume organs first.
Haast’s eagle lived in the forests, shrublands, and valley edges of New Zealand’s South Island, in an ecosystem almost entirely dominated by birds. With no native land mammals larger than bats, large herbivores such as moa acted like deer or antelope in other parts of the world, and Haast’s eagle filled the role of a big-cat-like apex predator.
The species went extinct shortly after the arrival of the first Māori settlers in New Zealand around the 13th century AD. Humans hunted moa heavily and burned large areas of forest, rapidly destroying the eagle’s main food source and much of its habitat. With the moa gone and its environment greatly altered, Haast’s eagle could not survive and disappeared by around the 15th century.
Haast’s eagle is widely thought to be the bird behind Māori legends of the giant man-killing bird called Pouākai or Hokioi. Its closest living relatives are surprisingly small eagles such as the little eagle of Australia, showing how rapidly it evolved giant size on isolated New Zealand. Fossil studies suggest its talons were as large as those of a tiger, and it may have been capable of killing a human as easily as it brought down a moa.

Toxodon was a large, heavy-bodied mammal that lived in South America during the late Pleistocene (the last part of the Ice Age), roughly from several hundred thousand years ago until about 11,000 years ago. It was one of the most common large herbivores found in the famous fossil sites studied by Charles Darwin, who collected its remains during his voyage on the HMS Beagle.
An adult Toxodon was about 2.7 meters long, around 1.5 meters tall at the shoulder or back, and may have weighed close to 1-1.5 tonnes - similar in mass to a modern rhinoceros or a large cow. It had a barrel-shaped body, short but strong legs, and a big head with a broad muzzle. Its skeleton suggests a somewhat semi-aquatic or hippo-like build, although it probably moved reasonably well on land.
Toxodon was a herbivore. Its teeth and jaw structure were adapted for grinding tough vegetation. It likely fed on grasses, reeds, and other low plants along rivers and wetlands, but it may also have browsed on soft leaves and aquatic plants. The high-crowned teeth indicate that it was well suited to eating abrasive, gritty food from dusty grasslands.
This animal lived in a range of environments across much of South America, including open grasslands, savannas, and floodplains, as well as the edges of lakes and rivers. These habitats would have provided both abundant vegetation and water, much like the environments where modern hippos and large grazing mammals are found today.
Toxodon went extinct near the end of the Pleistocene, at roughly the same time as many other large South American mammals such as giant ground sloths and glyptodonts. Its disappearance is usually linked to a combination of rapid climate change as the Ice Age ended and the arrival and spread of human populations, which may have hunted Toxodon or altered its habitats through fire and landscape changes.
Toxodon’s name means “arched tooth,” referring to the curved shape of its teeth. For a long time, scientists were unsure what major group of mammals it was most closely related to, because it looked like a mix of a rhino, a hippo, and a giant rodent. Recent studies using ancient DNA and proteins suggest that Toxodon and its relatives (notoungulates) were distant cousins of horses, rhinos, and tapirs, belonging to a very old South American branch of hoofed mammals.
